title: Summary
text: performed self-review code commented code, particularly hard--understand areas made corresponding changes documentation changes generate new warnings added tests prove fix effective feature works New existing unit tests pass locally changes dependent changes merged published downstream modules

title: Release Process
text: follow stable mainline approach main always reflects latest published version CRAN. Note small delay release merged main published CRAN.

title: Release Process
text: Create pre-release branch main (e.g., release/v3.1.0) Internal testing installing GitHub branch devtools::install_github("synthesizebio/rsynthbio@release/v3.1.0") Merge main validated Publish CRAN publish_to_cran github action

title: Baseline Models
text: Baseline models generate synthetic gene expression data metadata alone. describe biological conditions—tissue type, disease state, perturbations, cell type, etc.—model generates realistic expression profiles matching conditions. common use case: generating synthetic data conditions real data may scarce unavailable.

title: Baseline Models
text: gem-1-bulk: Bulk RNA-seq baseline model gem-1-sc: Single-cell RNA-seq baseline model
code: library(rsynthbio)

title: Baseline Models
text: structure query required API specific model. Use get_example_query() get correctly structured example chosen model. query consists : “sample generation”: Generates realistic-looking synthetic data measurement error (bulk ) “mean estimation”: Provides stable mean estimates expression levels (bulk single-cell) inputs: list biological conditions generate data input contains metadata (describing biological sample) num_samples (many samples generate).
code: # Get the example query structure for a specific model example_query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk")  # Inspect the query structure str(example_query)

title: Baseline Models
text: query ready, send API generate gene expression data: result list containing two data frames: metadata expression.
code: # Create a query for the bulk model query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk")  # Submit and get results result <- predict_query(query, model_id = "gem-1-bulk")

title: Baseline Models
text: Note: Single-cell models support "mean estimation" mode.
code: # Create a query for the single-cell model sc_query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-sc")  # Submit and get results sc_result <- predict_query(sc_query, model_id = "gem-1-sc")

title: Baseline Models
text: addition metadata, queries support several optional parameters control generation process.

title: Baseline Models
text: Controls type prediction model generates. parameter required queries. Available modes: “sample generation”: model generates realistic-looking synthetic data captures measurement error. mode useful want data mimics real experimental measurements. (Bulk ) “mean estimation”: model creates distribution capturing biological heterogeneity consistent supplied metadata, returns mean distribution. mode useful want stable estimate expected expression levels. (Bulk single-cell)
code: # Bulk query with sample generation bulk_query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk") bulk_query$sampling_strategy <- "sample generation"  # Bulk query with mean estimation bulk_query_mean <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk") bulk_query_mean$sampling_strategy <- "mean estimation"  # Single-cell query (must use mean estimation) sc_query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-sc") sc_query$sampling_strategy <- "mean estimation" # Required for single-cell

title: Baseline Models
text: Library size used converting predicted log CPM back raw counts. Higher values scale counts proportionally. Default: 10,000,000 bulk; 10,000 single-cell
code: # Create a query and add custom total_count query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk") query$total_count <- 5000000

title: Baseline Models
text: TRUE, model uses mean latent distribution (p(z|metadata)) instead sampling. removes randomness latent sampling produces deterministic outputs inputs. Default: FALSE (sampling enabled)
code: # Create a query and enable deterministic latents query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk") query$deterministic_latents <- TRUE

title: Baseline Models
text: Random seed reproducibility using stochastic sampling.
code: # Create a query with a specific seed query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk") query$seed <- 42

title: Baseline Models
text: can combine multiple parameters single query:
code: # Create a query and add multiple parameters query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk") query$total_count <- 8000000 query$deterministic_latents <- TRUE query$sampling_strategy <- "mean estimation"  results <- predict_query(query, model_id = "gem-1-bulk")

title: Baseline Models
text: input metadata list lists. full list valid metadata keys:

title: Baseline Models
text: age_years cell_line_ontology_id cell_type_ontology_id developmental_stage disease_ontology_id ethnicity genotype race sample_type (“cell line”, “organoid”, “”, “primary cells”, “primary tissue”, “xenograft”) sex (“male”, “female”) tissue_ontology_id

title: Baseline Models
text: perturbation_dose perturbation_ontology_id perturbation_time perturbation_type (“coculture”, “compound”, “control”, “crispr”, “genetic”, “infection”, “”, “overexpression”, “peptide biologic”, “shrna”, “sirna”)

title: Baseline Models
text: study (Bioproject ID) library_selection (e.g., “cDNA”, “polyA”, “Oligo-dT” - see https://ena-docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/submit/reads/webin-cli.html#permitted-values--library-selection) library_layout (“PAIRED”, “SINGLE”) platform (“illumina”)

title: Baseline Models
text: following valid values expected formats selected metadata keys: highly recommend using EMBL-EBI Ontology Lookup Service find valid IDs metadata. Models limited acceptable range metadata input values. provide value acceptable range, API return error.

title: Baseline Models
text: can customize query inputs fit specific research needs:
code: # Get a base query query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk")  # Adjust number of samples for the first input query$inputs[[1]]$num_samples <- 10  # Add a new condition query$inputs[[3]] <- list(   metadata = list(     sex = "male",     sample_type = "primary tissue",     tissue_ontology_id = "UBERON:0002371"   ),   num_samples = 5 )

title: Baseline Models
text: may want process data chunks save later use:
code: # Access metadata and expression matrices metadata <- result$metadata expression <- result$expression  # Check dimensions dim(expression)  # View metadata sample head(metadata) # Save results to RDS file saveRDS(result, "synthesize_results.rds")  # Load previously saved results result <- readRDS("synthesize_results.rds")  # Export as CSV write.csv(result$expression, "expression_matrix.csv") write.csv(result$metadata, "sample_metadata.csv")

title: Getting Started
text: can install rsynthbio CRAN: want development version, can install using remotes package install GitHub: installed, load package:
code: install.packages("rsynthbio") if (!("remotes" %in% installed.packages())) {   install.packages("remotes") } remotes::install_github("synthesizebio/rsynthbio") library(rsynthbio)

title: Getting Started
text: using Synthesize Bio API, need set API token. package provides secure way handle authentication: Loading API key session. can manually set token, don’t commit version control! can obtain API token registering Synthesize Bio.
code: # Securely prompt for and store your API token # The token will not be visible in the console set_synthesize_token()  # You can also store the token in your system keyring for persistence # across R sessions (requires the 'keyring' package) set_synthesize_token(use_keyring = TRUE) # In future sessions, load the stored token load_synthesize_token_from_keyring()  # Check if a token is already set has_synthesize_token() set_synthesize_token(token = "your-token-here")

title: Getting Started
text: Synthesize Bio provides several types models different use cases:

title: Getting Started
text: Generate synthetic gene expression data metadata alone. describe biological conditions (tissue type, disease state, perturbations, etc.) model generates realistic expression profiles. gem-1-bulk: Bulk RNA-seq baseline model gem-1-sc: Single-cell RNA-seq baseline model See Baseline Models vignette detailed usage.

title: Getting Started
text: Generate expression data conditioned real reference sample. allows “anchor” existing expression profile applying perturbations modifications. gem-1-bulk_reference-conditioning: Bulk RNA-seq reference conditioning model gem-1-sc_reference-conditioning: Single-cell RNA-seq reference conditioning model See Reference Conditioning vignette detailed usage.

title: Getting Started
text: Infer metadata observed expression data. Given gene expression profile, predict likely biological characteristics (cell type, tissue, disease state, etc.). gem-1-bulk_predict-metadata: Bulk RNA-seq metadata prediction model gem-1-sc_predict-metadata: Single-cell RNA-seq metadata prediction model See Metadata Prediction vignette detailed usage. baseline models available users. can check models available programmatically, use list_models(). Contact us support@synthesize.bio questions.

title: Getting Started
text: can check models available programmatically:
code: # Check available models list_models()

title: Getting Started
text: ’s quick example using baseline model: detailed examples advanced usage, see model-specific vignettes linked .
code: # Get an example query structure query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk")  # Submit the query and get results result <- predict_query(query, model_id = "gem-1-bulk")  # Access the results metadata <- result$metadata expression <- result$expression

title: Getting Started
code: sessionInfo()

title: Getting Started
text: Package Source Code File Bug Reports

title: Metadata Prediction
text: Metadata prediction models infer biological metadata observed expression data. Given gene expression profile, model predicts likely biological characteristics cell type, tissue, disease state, . useful want : Annotate samples unknown origin Validate sample labels expression patterns Discover potential mislabeled contaminated samples Understand biological characteristics captured expression data

title: Metadata Prediction
text: gem-1-bulk_predict-metadata: Bulk RNA-seq metadata prediction model gem-1-sc_predict-metadata: Single-cell RNA-seq metadata prediction model Note: endpoints may require 1-2 minutes startup time scaled . Plan accordingly interactive use.
code: library(rsynthbio)

title: Metadata Prediction
text: Metadata prediction encodes expression data model’s latent space uses classifiers predict likely metadata values sample. model returns: Classifier probabilities: categorical metadata field, probability distribution possible values Predicted labels: likely value metadata field Latent representations: biological, technical, perturbation latent vectors

title: Metadata Prediction
text: Metadata prediction queries simpler model types—need provide expression counts: query structure includes: inputs: list count vectors, element named list counts field containing expression values seed (optional): Random seed reproducibility
code: # Get the example query structure example_query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk_predict-metadata")  # Inspect the query structure str(example_query)

title: Metadata Prediction
text: ’s complete example predicting metadata expression samples:
code: # Start with example query structure query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk_predict-metadata")  # Replace with your actual expression counts # Each input should be a list with a counts vector query$inputs <- list(   list(counts = sample1_counts),   list(counts = sample2_counts),   list(counts = sample3_counts) )  # Optional: set seed for reproducibility query$seed <- 42  # Submit the query result <- predict_query(query, model_id = "gem-1-bulk_predict-metadata")

title: Metadata Prediction
text: predicting metadata single sample:
code: query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk_predict-metadata")  # Single sample query$inputs <- list(   list(counts = my_sample_counts) )  result <- predict_query(query, model_id = "gem-1-bulk_predict-metadata")  # Access the predictions print(result$metadata)

title: Metadata Prediction
text: list expression count vectors. element named list containing: counts: vector non-negative integers representing gene expression counts
code: query$inputs <- list(   list(counts = c(0, 12, 5, 0, 33, 7, ...)), # Sample 1   list(counts = c(3, 0, 0, 7, 1, 0, ...)) # Sample 2 )

title: Metadata Prediction
text: Random seed reproducibility.
code: query$seed <- 123

title: Metadata Prediction
text: results metadata prediction include several components:

title: Metadata Prediction
text: metadata data frame contains predicted values sample:
code: # View predicted metadata head(result$outputs$metadata)  # Access specific predictions result$outputs$metadata$cell_type_ontology_id result$outputs$metadata$tissue_ontology_id result$outputs$metadata$disease_ontology_id

title: Metadata Prediction
text: categorical metadata fields, model returns probability distributions possible values. useful understanding prediction confidence:
code: # If probabilities are included in the output # Access cell type probabilities for first sample # The exact structure depends on the API response format  # Example: viewing top predicted cell types cell_type_probs <- result$classifier_probs$cell_type[[1]] head(sort(cell_type_probs, decreasing = TRUE))

title: Metadata Prediction
text: model also returns latent vectors capture biological, technical, perturbation characteristics:
code: # Access latent representations (if returned) biological_latents <- result$latents$biological technical_latents <- result$latents$technical

title: Metadata Prediction
text: Annotate unlabeled samples predicted metadata:
code: # Load your unlabeled samples unlabeled_counts <- read.csv("unlabeled_samples.csv", row.names = 1)  # Create query query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk_predict-metadata") query$inputs <- lapply(1:ncol(unlabeled_counts), function(i) {   list(counts = unlabeled_counts[, i]) })  # Predict metadata result <- predict_query(query, model_id = "gem-1-bulk_predict-metadata")  # Combine with sample IDs annotations <- result$outputs$metadata annotations$sample_id <- colnames(unlabeled_counts)

title: Metadata Prediction
text: Validate existing sample labels predicted metadata:
code: # Compare predicted vs. provided labels provided_labels <- c("UBERON:0002107", "UBERON:0002107", "UBERON:0000955", "UBERON:0000955") predicted_labels <- result$outputs$metadata$tissue_ontology_id  # Identify potential mismatches mismatches <- which(provided_labels != predicted_labels) if (length(mismatches) > 0) {   message("Potential mislabeled samples: ", paste(mismatches, collapse = ", ")) }

title: Metadata Prediction
text: Understand batch-specific technical characteristics:
code: # Group samples by batch batch_labels <- c("batch1", "batch1", "batch2", "batch2")  # Check if technical predictions cluster by batch # This can help identify batch effects tapply(result$outputs$latents$technical[, 1], batch_labels, mean)

title: Metadata Prediction
text: counts vector sample must match model’s expected number genes. length doesn’t match, API return validation error. Use get_example_query() see expected structure.

title: Metadata Prediction
text: Ensure counts gene order expected model. gene order match baseline model expects—can retrieve prediction result’s gene_order field.

title: Metadata Prediction
text: count values must non-negative integers. Floats whole numbers (like 10.0) accepted, negative values cause validation errors.

title: Reference Conditioning
text: Reference conditioning models generate expression data conditioned real reference sample. allows “anchor” existing expression profile applying perturbations modifications. useful want : Simulate effect perturbation specific sample Generate expression profiles preserve biological technical characteristics reference Create synthetic “treated vs. control” pairs

title: Reference Conditioning
text: gem-1-bulk_reference-conditioning: Bulk RNA-seq reference conditioning model gem-1-sc_reference-conditioning: Single-cell RNA-seq reference conditioning model Note: endpoints may require 1-2 minutes startup time scaled . Plan accordingly interactive use.
code: library(rsynthbio)

title: Reference Conditioning
text: Reference conditioning encodes biological technical characteristics real expression sample, generates new expression data : Preserves biological/technical latent space reference Applies perturbation metadata specify Returns synthetic expression reflects perturbation effect specific sample

title: Reference Conditioning
text: Reference conditioning queries require different inputs baseline models: query structure includes: inputs: list input contains: counts: reference expression counts (named list counts vector) metadata: Perturbation-metadata (see ) num_samples: many samples generate conditioning: latent spaces condition (typically ["biological", "technical"]) sampling_strategy: "mean estimation" "sample generation"
code: # Get the example query structure example_query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk_reference-conditioning")  # Inspect the query structure str(example_query)

title: Reference Conditioning
text: Unlike baseline models, reference conditioning queries accept perturbation metadata fields: perturbation_ontology_id perturbation_type perturbation_time perturbation_dose biological technical metadata inferred reference expression.

title: Reference Conditioning
text: ’s complete example simulating drug treatment effect reference sample:
code: # Start with example query structure query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk_reference-conditioning")  # Replace with your actual reference counts # The counts vector must match the model's expected gene order and length query$inputs[[1]]$counts <- list(counts = your_reference_counts)  # Specify the perturbation query$inputs[[1]]$metadata <- list(   perturbation_ontology_id = "CHEMBL25", # Aspirin (ChEMBL ID)   perturbation_type = "compound",   perturbation_time = "24h",   perturbation_dose = "10uM" )  query$inputs[[1]]$num_samples <- 3  # Set the sampling strategy query$sampling_strategy <- "mean estimation"  # Submit the query result <- predict_query(query, model_id = "gem-1-bulk_reference-conditioning")

title: Reference Conditioning
text: Simulate effect knocking specific gene:
code: query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk_reference-conditioning")  # Your reference sample counts query$inputs[[1]]$counts <- list(counts = control_sample_counts)  # CRISPR knockout of TP53 query$inputs[[1]]$metadata <- list(   perturbation_ontology_id = "ENSG00000141510", # TP53 Ensembl ID   perturbation_type = "crispr" )  query$inputs[[1]]$num_samples <- 5  result <- predict_query(query, model_id = "gem-1-bulk_reference-conditioning")

title: Reference Conditioning
text: Controls latent spaces conditioned reference. Default ["biological", "technical"]. conditioned, model preserves biological identity technical characteristics reference sample.

title: Reference Conditioning
text: Controls type prediction: “sample generation”: Generates realistic-looking synthetic data measurement error. (Bulk ) “mean estimation”: Provides stable mean estimates. (Bulk single-cell)
code: query$sampling_strategy <- "mean estimation"

title: Reference Conditioning
text: Controls whether preserve reference’s library size: FALSE (default): output’s total count taken reference expression (sum counts). Use want synthetic sample preserve reference’s library size. TRUE: Forces model use total_count parameter value (default) instead reference’s library size.
code: # Preserve reference library size (default) query$fixed_total_count <- FALSE  # Or force a specific library size query$fixed_total_count <- TRUE query$total_count <- 10000000

title: Reference Conditioning
text: Library size used converting predicted log CPM back raw counts. effective fixed_total_count = TRUE. Default: 10,000,000 bulk; 10,000 single-cell

title: Reference Conditioning
text: TRUE, model uses mean latent distribution (p(z|metadata) perturbation, q(z|x) conditioned components) instead sampling. produces deterministic, reproducible outputs. Default: FALSE
code: query$deterministic_latents <- TRUE

title: Reference Conditioning
text: Random seed reproducibility.
code: query$seed <- 42

title: Reference Conditioning
text: result structure similar baseline models:
code: # Access metadata and expression matrices metadata <- result$metadata expression <- result$expression  # Compare to your reference dim(expression) head(metadata)

title: Reference Conditioning
text: conditioning biological technical latents, can directly compare generated expression reference identify perturbation effects:
code: # Your reference (input) counts reference_cpm <- your_reference_counts / sum(your_reference_counts) * 1e6  # Generated (perturbed) counts generated_cpm <- expression[1, ] / sum(expression[1, ]) * 1e6  # Log fold change log2fc <- log2(generated_cpm + 1) - log2(reference_cpm + 1)  # Identify top changed genes head(sort(log2fc, decreasing = TRUE), 20)

title: Reference Conditioning
text: reference counts vector must match model’s expected number genes. length doesn’t match, API return validation error. Use get_example_query() see expected structure ensure counts vector correct length.

title: Reference Conditioning
text: Ensure reference counts gene order expected model. response includes gene_order field specifies expected order.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Synthesize Bio. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Synthesize Bio (2025). rsynthbio: Synthesize Bio API Wrapper. R package version 4.0.0, https://github.com/synthesizebio/rsynthbio.
code: @Manual{,   title = {rsynthbio: Synthesize Bio API Wrapper},   author = {{Synthesize Bio}},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 4.0.0},   url = {https://github.com/synthesizebio/rsynthbio}, }

title: Synthesize Bio API Wrapper
text: rsynthbio R package provides convenient interface Synthesize Bio API, allowing users generate realistic gene expression data based specified biological conditions. package enables researchers easily access AI-generated transcriptomic data various modalities, including bulk RNA-seq single-cell RNA-seq. generate datasets without code, use web platform. See full documentation . questions, suggestions, support, email us support@synthesize.bio.

title: Synthesize Bio API Wrapper
text: can install rsynthbio CRAN: install development version GitHub:
code: install.packages("rsynthbio") remotes::install_github("synthesizebio/rsynthbio")

title: Synthesize Bio API Wrapper
text: Set API token (obtain one app.synthesize.bio):
code: library(rsynthbio)  # Securely prompt for your token (recommended) set_synthesize_token()  # Or store in system keyring for persistence across sessions set_synthesize_token(use_keyring = TRUE)  # Load from keyring in future sessions load_synthesize_token_from_keyring()

title: Synthesize Bio API Wrapper
code: library(rsynthbio)  # See available models list_models()  # Get an example query for bulk RNA-seq query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk")  # Generate synthetic expression data result <- predict_query(query, model_id = "gem-1-bulk")  # Access the results metadata <- result$metadata expression <- result$expression

title: Synthesize Bio API Wrapper
text: baseline models available users. can check models available programmatically, use list_models(). Contact us support@synthesize.bio questions.

title: Synthesize Bio API Wrapper
text: detailed usage instructions, see vignettes: Getting Started — Installation, authentication, overview Baseline Models — Generate expression metadata Reference Conditioning — Condition real expression data Metadata Prediction — Infer metadata expression

title: Synthesize Bio API Wrapper
text: Free usage Synthesize Bio limited. exceed limit, receive error message. generate samples, please contact us support@synthesize.bio.

title: Make Authenticated API Request — make_api_request
text: Internal helper make authenticated GET requests

title: Predict Gene Expression — predict_query
text: Sends query Synthesize Bio API prediction retrieves gene expression samples. function sends query API processes response usable data frames.

title: Predict Gene Expression — predict_query
code: predict_query(   query,   model_id,   api_base_url = API_BASE_URL,   poll_interval_seconds = DEFAULT_POLL_INTERVAL_SECONDS,   poll_timeout_seconds = DEFAULT_POLL_TIMEOUT_SECONDS,   return_download_url = FALSE )

title: Predict Gene Expression — predict_query
text: query list representing query data send API. Use `get_example_query()` generate example. query supports additional optional fields: `total_count` (integer): Library size used converting predicted log CPM         back raw counts. Higher values scale counts proportionally. `deterministic_latents` (logical): TRUE, model uses mean         latent distribution instead sampling, producing deterministic outputs         inputs. Useful reproducibility. `seed` (integer): Random seed reproducibility. model_id Character string specifying model ID (e.g., "gem-1-bulk", "gem-1-sc"). Use `list_models()` see available models. api_base_url base URL API server. Default API_BASE_URL. poll_interval_seconds Seconds polling attempts status endpoint. Default DEFAULT_POLL_INTERVAL_SECONDS (2). poll_timeout_seconds Maximum total seconds wait timing . Default DEFAULT_POLL_TIMEOUT_SECONDS (900 = 15 minutes). return_download_url Logical, TRUE, returns list containing signed download URL instead parsing data frames. Default FALSE.

title: Predict Gene Expression — predict_query
text: list. `return_download_url` `FALSE` (default), list contains         two data frames: `metadata` `expression`. `TRUE`, list         contains `download_url` empty `metadata` `expression` data frames.

title: Predict Gene Expression — predict_query
code: # Set your API key (in practice, use a more secure method) if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{  # To start using rsynthbio, first you need to have an account with synthesize.bio. # Go here to create one: https://app.synthesize.bio/  set_synthesize_token()  # Get available models models <- list_models()  # Create a query for a specific model query <- get_example_query(model_id = "gem-1-bulk")  # Request raw counts result <- predict_query(query, model_id = "gem-1-bulk")  # Access the results metadata <- result$metadata expression <- result$expression  # Explore the top expressed genes in the first sample head(sort(expression[1, ], decreasing = TRUE))  # Use deterministic latents for reproducible results query$deterministic_latents <- TRUE result_det <- predict_query(query, model_id = "gem-1-bulk")  # Specify a custom total count (library size) query$total_count <- 5000000 result_custom <- predict_query(query, model_id = "gem-1-bulk") } # }

what: Set Synthesize Bio API Token — set_synthesize_token
title: Set Synthesize Bio API Token — set_synthesize_token
text: Securely prompts stores Synthesize Bio API token environment. function uses getPass securely handle token input without displaying console. token stored SYNTHESIZE_API_KEY environment variable current R session.

title: Set Synthesize Bio API Token — set_synthesize_token
code: set_synthesize_token(use_keyring = FALSE, token = NULL)

title: Set Synthesize Bio API Token — set_synthesize_token
text: use_keyring Logical, whether also store token securely system keyring future sessions. Defaults FALSE. token Character, optional. provided, uses token instead prompting. parameter used non-interactive scripts.

title: Set Synthesize Bio API Token — set_synthesize_token
text: Invisibly returns TRUE successful.

title: Set Synthesize Bio API Token — set_synthesize_token
code: # Interactive prompt for token if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ set_synthesize_token()  # Provide token directly (less secure, not recommended for interactive use) set_synthesize_token(token = "your-token-here")  # Store in system keyring for future sessions set_synthesize_token(use_keyring = TRUE) } # }

title: Transform Standard Model Output (Internal) — transform_baseline_output
text: list :         - metadata: data.frame containing sample metadata         - expression: data.frame containing combined gene expression data         - latents: data.frame containing embeddings (requested)

title: rsynthbio 4.0.0
text: CRAN release: 2025-12-03

title: rsynthbio 4.0.0
text: Model Agnostic Client: client updated support model ID via model_id parameter, enabling support current future Synthesize Bio models without package updates. Dynamic Model Support: Removed hardcoded model lists validations allow flexible usage new models.

title: rsynthbio 4.0.0
text: predict_query(): Now requires model_id parameter. New Query Helper: get_example_query(model_id) replaces get_valid_query(). Removed Functions: get_valid_query(), get_valid_modalities(), validate_modality() removed favor dynamic model support.
